content:
If the old PC is still available, do this:

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: outlook.com accounts in TB use an oauth:// token in Saved Passwords, which is different from the normal account password used to access the account in webmail.

content:
In Thunderbird In 'Quick Filter' toolbar The icon which is 'Envelope with a dot in top left corner' is 'Show Only Unread Messages' filter option. You would select it to only show unread emails and delect to show all emails.

If using 'Table View' you will see column headers. One column header shows an 'Envelope with a dot in top left corner' and if you click on it - it means 'Sort by Unread' and each email will have a green dot in that column if status is 'Unread'.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: It might be that remote images are not allowed. You can check setting for that at setting>privacy&security
creator: davidsk

content:
Ordinary mail accounts do not auto display remote content for security reasons. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/remote-content-in-messages

re : my email news shots

But are you talking about a 'Feed' account ? That type of account should be auto displaying remote content because it's expecting news and editorial stuff which has remote content and you have subscribed to the feed account.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Direct after the update to 132.0 (linux,64-bit) thunderbird stopped downloading the body of my emails

Where did you get v132.0 from? From a repository of your distribution?

Note, the only supported version is 128esr, currently at 128.4.2esr. It's available at https://www.thunderbird.net/

Version 132.0 has no release notes, no change log, no announcements and nothing on the main website because it is the build out for when monthly releases becomes "production". At present it is a place holder and anything you find for download should be considered beta in terms of quality and function. Until monthly versions are formally announced these are literally equivalent to beta, not recommended for production. If you want to use pre-release software you are better off using beta which will get frequent fixes, monthlies will not.

Version 128esr is being delivered via the ESR channel. Users will eventually be able to choose monthly releases, which will be announced when all the pieces are in place.
creator: christ1

creator: @next

content:
Password is usually the same password you would use to access the webmail account via a browser.

But you say you can receive emails so that password must be good. The password is already stored in Thunderbird. Check this location for the stored password and make sure the smtp outgoing password is the same as the good incoming password.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll down to Passwords section
  • Clickon 'Saved Passwords'
  • click on 'Show PAsswords'
  • If at any point you get prompted for a password in order to access them - when you start up computer, the first thing you get asked is to logon to either User Account or Microsoft account - it wants that computer password.

To Edit: Right click on the smtp line and select 'Edit Password' completely remove and then carefully type the correct password so it matches the good incoming password.

It would also help to know what error message you are getting - post an image of it.

It would also be useful to know what server you are using because there has been several changes recently to some servers and Microsoft servers have seen many changes which have effected outgoing smtp especially regarding passwords and smtp settings.

In Thunderbird Help > Troubleshooting Information Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' Copy all data in that section and paste into this forum question. Or post an image shwoing that section.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Is the correct password stored in Thunderbird ?

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll down to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Click on 'Show Passwords'

If no - right click on line and select 'Edit Password' Remove all contents and then carefullt type in the new/correct password. Do this for both incoming and smtp outgoin glines. click on 'Close' Exit Thunderbird and wait a few moments for background process to complete then restart Thunderbird.

Please note: Password is the one you use to access the webmail account via a browser. Password maybe correct but is it correct for the server settings being used? Password maybe correct but is it correct for the username = email address ?

You would need to post information on what server settings you currently have got set up. eg: In Thunderbird Help > Troubleshooting Information Scroll down to 'Mail and News Acounts' Copy all the data and paste it into this forum question. OR post images of server settings in Account Settings an SMTP settings

It would be useful to see an image of the error message. Do you have a problem both sending and receiving ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Located a good Help Article on correct server settings:

  • https://help.earthlink.net/portal/en/kb/articles/email-server-settings

EarthLink IMAP Settings IMAP Settings are the same regardless of your EarthLink domain. The same settings are used for @earthlink.net, @mindspring.com, @ix.netcom.com or any other EarthLink domain.

  • Incoming Server: imap.earthlink.net
  • Port: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • User name: Use your full email address.


EarthLink POP3 Settings Incoming POP3 settings are unique to each EarthLink domain. The format is pop.(domain name). The outgoing server is the same regardless of domain.

  • Pop Incoming Server: pop.earthlink.net (pop.mindspring.com, pop.peoplepc.com, etc)
  • Port: 995
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • User name: Use your full email address

SMTP

  • Outgoing Server: smtpauth.earthlink.net (same for all EarthLink domains)
  • Port : 587
  • Connection Security: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • User name: Use your full email address
creator: Toad-Hall
